titleInfo.title: McKinley High School Oral History Project: History of the School
titleInfo.subTitle: Eva R. Legard oral history interview, 1995

name.description: Eva Legard was born in Lafayette, La., in 1924, and moved to Baton Rouge in 1938. A 1942 graduate of McKinley High School, she worked for many years at Southern University, retiring from the registrar's office. She was the first African American female member of the East Baton Rouge Parish School Board. Active in promoting public education, she worked with the Girl Scouts and Boy Scouts, and with her church, St. Francis Xavier. Legard was a longtime member and president of the Board of the Baton Rouge Council on Human Relations. In 1986, she received their Powell-Reznikoff Humanitarian Award. She died in 2005 at age eighty.

mods.abstract: Legard talks about her years at McKinley High School (1938-1942), and the changes she's seen in schools and education. She discusses her favorite classes and teachers, fellow students, discipline, teachers' involvement in students' lives, and the role of academics and athletics. She briefly touches on the Civil Rights Movement and her election to and service on the East Baton Rouge Parish School Board.
